title: Amelia Vargas
text:
Hi! I‚Äôm Amelia, a data scientist based in the Pacific Northwest.
I‚Äôm a Senior Research Analyst with the State of Oregon. I became the first R Admin for my agency, the Department of Consumer and Business Services, in 2022. Most of my work is related to creating new statistical analyses, building analytical tools for internal teams, and providing guidance on research and evaluation methods.
I‚Äôm currently interested in predictive modeling and using deep learning (PyTorch) in insurance.

Education
M.Sc. in Mathematics from Dalhousie University, Canada
M.Sc. thesis: A Geometric Study of Superintegrable Systems [arXiv]
B.Sc. in Physics and B.A. in Mathematics from California State University, Fullerton, USA


Studies
2022 Oregon Workers‚Äô Compensation Premium Rate Ranking Study
D. Gallogly, A. Vargas
PDF
Statistical analysis of reporting of student genders in Oregon‚Äôs public schools
A. Vargas, A. Vargas
2018 Oregon Statewide Annual Report Card.
ODE
Newspaper Archives + Text Mining = Rich Sources of Historical Geospatial Data: A Flood Database Case Study
A. Yzaguirre, R. Warren, M. Smit
IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science, Volume 34, conference 1 (2016).
IOP Science
Detecting environmental disasters in digital news archives
A. Yzaguirre, R. Warren, M. Smit
2015 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data), pp.¬†2027-2035 (2015).

J. F. Gallimore, A. L. Yzaguirre, J. Jakoboski, M. J. Stevenosky, D. J. Axon, S. A. Baum, C. L. Buchanan, M. Elitzur, M. Elvis, C. P. O‚ÄôDea, A. Robinson
The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series, Volume 187, Issue 1, pp.¬†172-211 (2010).

Recommendations

How to Solve It by George P√≥lya.
Statistical Rethinking by Richard McElreath.
{tidymodels} and Tidy Modeling with R by Max Kuhn & Julia Silge
Applied Predictive Modeling by Kuhn & Johnson
Coffee

title: Amelia Vargas
text:
I‚Äôm . This is my personal website, which I started to share my projects, learnings, code (mostly R and Python), and thoughts on various topics in data science.
I work at Yelp as a Data Science Analyst where, among other things, I design and analyze online experiments. Before that, I worked for Ardea Outcomes, a contract research organization supporting pharmaceutical companies in clinical trials. My background is in Physics. I earned my MSc from Dalhousie University, and my BSc from the University of Prince Edward Island.
I‚Äôm currently a Senior Research Analyst with the State of Oregon. I‚Äôm research and data teams in a variety of sectors including public education, I‚Äôm passionate about coding, statistical modeling, and analytics .

title: This is a Quarto blog
text:
This post is to show some of Quarto‚Äôs blog features. I might revisit and edit this post from time to time to experiment with the layout and appearance of my blog. When I first created my blog I used this post to figure out the light and dark toggle options.


Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nam suscipit est nec dui eleifend, at dictum elit ullamcorper. Aliquam feugiat dictum bibendum. Praesent fermentum laoreet quam, cursus volutpat odio dapibus in. Fusce luctus porttitor vehicula. Donec ac tortor nisi. Donec at lectus tortor. Morbi tempor, nibh non euismod viverra, metus arcu aliquet elit, sed fringilla urna leo vel purus.


This is inline code plus a small code chunk.

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(scales)

# inspired by tmwr.org
data(ames, package = "modeldata")

ggplot(ames, aes(x = Sale_Price)) + 
  geom_histogram(bins = 50, col= "white") + 
  scale_x_log10(labels = label_dollar(scale_cut = cut_long_scale())) +
  theme(
    axis.text.x  = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.margin = margin(0, 1, 0, 0, "cm")
  )








Transforming OLS estimatesMaximizing likelihood




Code
preds_lm %>% 
  ggplot(aes(body_mass_g, bill_length_mm, col = correct)) +
  geom_jitter(size = 4, alpha = 0.6) +
  facet_wrap(vars(species)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('grey60', thematic::okabe_ito(3)[3])) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(3000, 6000, 1000)) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 12) +
  theme(
    legend.position = 'top', 
    panel.background = element_rect(color = 'black'),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  ) +
  labs(
    x = 'Body mass (in g)',
    y = 'Bill length (in mm)'
  )









Code
glm.mod <- glm(sex ~ body_mass_g + bill_length_mm + species, family = binomial, data = dat)

preds <- dat %>% 
  mutate(
    prob.fit = glm.mod$fitted.values,
    prediction = if_else(prob.fit > 0.5, 'male', 'female'),
    correct = if_else(sex == prediction, 'correct', 'incorrect')
  )


preds %>% 
  ggplot(aes(body_mass_g, bill_length_mm, col = correct)) +
  geom_jitter(size = 4, alpha = 0.6) +
  facet_wrap(vars(species)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(3000, 6000, 1000)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c('grey60', thematic::okabe_ito(3)[3])) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    legend.position = 'top', 
    panel.background = element_rect(color = 'black'),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  ) +
  labs(
    x = 'Body mass (in g)',
    y = 'Bill length (in mm)'
  )










\[
\int_0^1 f(x) \ dx
\]








geom_density(
  mapping = NULL,
  data = NULL,
  stat = "density",
  position = "identity",
  ...,
  na.rm = FALSE,
  orientation = NA,
  show.legend = NA,
  inherit.aes = TRUE,
  outline.type = "upper"
)


stat_density(
  mapping = NULL,
  data = NULL,
  geom = "area",
  position = "stack",
  ...,
  bw = "nrd0",
  adjust = 1,
  kernel = "gaussian",
  n = 512,
  trim = FALSE,
  na.rm = FALSE,
  orientation = NA,
  show.legend = NA,
  inherit.aes = TRUE
)







ggplot(data = gapminder::gapminder, mapping = aes(x = lifeExp, fill = continent)) +
  stat_density(position = "identity", alpha = 0.5)




Bla bla bla. This is a caption in the margin. Super cool isn‚Äôt it?

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
I‚Äôm using Quarto to begin my blog journey.

What kinds of posts might you find here?
Currently, I‚Äôm working through the Tidy Modeling with R book by Max Kuhn and Julia Silge. So I might have some posts related to that. Who knows what other types of posts I‚Äôll be writing here. I shall make no promises nor predictions.


Dark theme blog
I love reading in dark mode. There are a handful of available dark themes that come pre-installed with Quarto:

Cyborg

Darkly

Slate

Superhero

‚Ä¶and maybe Solar and Vapor?
I was a fan of Slate until I realized I didn‚Äôt like the vertical lines it has in places like the navigation bar.

I was also very tempted by how cool Vapor looks. I still am. But in the end, I wanted simplicity in my theme and decided not to use any of these. I was following along with Albert Rapp‚Äôs ultimate guide to starting a Quarto blog and decided to build on his theme.scss example to customize my blog‚Äôs settings. This made it easy to figure out a minimum set of variables to configure to get the dark theme setup. Here are the variables to modify if you‚Äôre interested in setting up a simple dark theme:


snippet of my theme-dark.scss

$body-bg: $black !default; 
$body-color: $white !default;
$code-color: #bb8acf !default;
$code-block-bg: #212529 !default;
$code-block-border-left: #bb8acf !default;



What‚Äôs next?
I might add a list of bloggers and articles that have helped or inspired me along the way. But otherwise, that‚Äôs all for this post for now.
Happy blogging! ‚å®Ô∏è‚ú®
